title: PremiumcryptoHub
author: PremiumcryptoHub
content: Microstrategy CEO Michael Saylor is one of the world's largest bitcoin holders. His company already holds about $17 billion worth of bitcoins. In a recent interview with The New Zealand Herald, Michael Saylor says,Quote"Just like Satoshi left a million Bitcoin to the universe, so I’m leaving whatever I’ve got to the civilization,” the MicroStrategy co-founder said.Michael Saylor also said that,Quote“I’m a single guy, I have no children — when I’m gone, I’m gone. Just like Satoshi left a million Bitcoin to the universe, so I’m leaving whatever I’ve got to the civilization,”.https://decrypt.co/287667/bitcoin-billionaire-michael-saylor-satoshi-nakamoto

comments.author: Free Market Capitalist
comments.body: He has a niece, he could leave her something, even if it is little. I have never understood these people who keep accumulating during their lifetime to leave nothing to their relatives when they die, like Buffet.The bad thing about this “donation”, if it is like Satoshi, is that in the end it will be necessary to make a change in the protocol to allow subdivisions beyond satoshis, with all the bitcoins lost and the foreseeable appreciation.It would also be nice to know of the distinction Michael Saylor bitcoins vs bitcoins that Michael Saylor owns through MSTR shares. If when he dies he has no heirs I would imagine his shares would go on to appreciate the rest? I recently bought some myself by the way.

comments.author: PX-Z
comments.body: I doubt he will do that, that's too much money, now that he mentions it anyone who is in relation to him either a family (extended), friend, business partner, etc. will be interested on that. Yet i only think this is just another hype for Bitcoin for his and his company's benefit, of course, to everyone here as well.

comments.author: ImThour
comments.body: I mean we would never know right? I know we can track the Bitcoin transactions of MicroStrategy's wallet but do we even know if he's the sole controller of that wallet or it's in control by someone else? As I don't think Saylor know how to use a hardware wallet. If you remember, he was Anti-Bitcoin some years back. Only hes in for the money, I cannot prove that but that's my belief. But yea, no one will take Bitcoin with them once they are gone.

comments.author: DeathAngel
comments.body: Whilst it’s very honourable to the community & makes everybody else’s coins worth slightly more, I think there must be some relative somewhere he can pass them onto. It’s a shame really that such a successful, rich person hasn’t got any heirs. The kind of generational wealth he already has really should be continued. He’s not too old to Father a child with a younger woman, maybe he still has time.

comments.author: Rikafip
comments.body: Quote from: PX-Z on October 22, 2024, 03:04:18 PMI doubt he will do that, that's too much money,Thing is, its very easy to give away money when you are dead because you can't really take it to the grave (I mean you can, but you won't be able to use it there  ) so these words that he will leave his bitcoins " to civilisation" mean nothing really. And the same thing goes for Warren Buffer who also plans to do the same thing with his billions. Want to help the world? Start now.

comments.author: Richbased
comments.body: Michael Saylor is a bitcoin lover and he has said so many positive things about bitcoin and MicroStrategy has also played important role in bitcoin's development due to the large amount of bitcoin the company is holding but just like other users has given their opinion about him giving his wealth to his relatives if what he said about not having children is true, so am of the opinion that even if he want to give his bitcoin to civilization and humanity he should also consider giving part of his holdings to people who are close and dear to him, however if Michael Saylor leaves his bitcoin for civilization it will further boast the confidence of many bitcoin lovers and hodlers and also make others consider doing such for further development of the most valued crypto asset which will be a good step towards the adoption process.

comments.body: Quote from: cryptoWODL on October 22, 2024, 03:42:07 PMYes I recently saw this news on the social media Twitter (X) that Michael Saylor says, he wants to leave his Bitcoin to the civilization like Satoshi Nakamoto, the creator of Bitcoin.I don't know if it's completely true but after seeing this news I googled it and even read an article there and found out that Michael Saylor was married to a woman named Patricia Saylor and they had five children.~snipI'm not quite sure of the accuracy of that write up. Is it not surprising that wikipedia doesn't have any of those information? Because I checked (or maybe I didn't check well). Wiki usually contains someone's general information from the majority I've seen, but Michael saylor's information talks more about his business and career.Quote from: PremiumcryptoHub on October 22, 2024, 02:50:23 PMMicrostrategy CEO Michael Saylor is one of the world's largest bitcoin holders. His company already holds about $17 billion worth of bitcoins. In a recent interview with The New Zealand Herald, Michael Saylor says,Quote"Just like Satoshi left a million Bitcoin to the universe, so I’m leaving whatever I’ve got to the civilization,” the MicroStrategy co-founder said.Michael Saylor also said that,Quote“I’m a single guy, I have no children — when I’m gone, I’m gone. Just like Satoshi left a million Bitcoin to the universe, so I’m leaving whatever I’ve got to the civilization,”.These are quite some interesting statements that's coming from him, but not sure if he is actually leaving those Bitcoin as a donation or lost coins that won't be accessed again. In satoshi's case, it was more of like lost coins, which I think saylor should have been more specific. Making such statement feels like there isn't anyone close to him that understands Bitcoin that much, because I guess he would have preferred to leave such fortune to someone like that.

comments.author: Die_empty
comments.body: Quote from: DeathAngel on October 22, 2024, 03:28:35 PMWhilst it’s very honourable to the community & makes everybody else’s coins worth slightly more, I think there must be some relative somewhere he can pass them onto. It’s a shame really that such a successful, rich person hasn’t got any heirs. The kind of generational wealth he already has really should be continued. He’s not too old to Father a child with a younger woman, maybe he still has time. I am surprised that Michael Saylor dont have a child. This kind of decision not to have any heir is popular in most developed nations. In my country having children is almost compulsory for everyone. The rich who cannot have children naturally usually seek other means to have successors. But that's his decision and we have to respect it. Satoshi left his fortune in wallets and didn't donate it to any charity. I hope this is not the path Micheal is following. It will be better for him to give the funds to people who need it. There is an increase in refugees, sicknesses and natural disaster victims that need such donations. I observe that people donate to medical courses if they fall sick, maybe this could make him donate to research and development of drugs and vaccines.

comments.author: Z-tight
comments.body: I believe Satoshi's cause is a bit different here and understandable, he is the anonymous creator of BTC and he probably never wanted to leave any traces of who he really was, so he left his coins unspent. However, i don't see any reason why Saylor wouldn't want to pass down any of his coins to anyone, even if he stays unmarried until death and has no heirs, he can work on a way to pass it down to charity or any good cause, but it is his money anyway.

comments.author: cabron
comments.body: He isn't like Satoshi who created BTC, I doubt people will learn about him and be grateful for him leaving BTC unused after years. Yes, it can add value but maybe just the 5% of the earth population who knows BTC.If he is willing to leave all his BTC, why not just help build something for a country he loves, something that will remember him for hundreds of years like rebuilding the bridge that collapsed?  Because at some point, this is somewhat like hype again. We all know crypto is all about hype every time there is a bull market.

So Saylor just left his Bitcoin? my two cents is still not sure because he is still a businessman regardless of his desire to compensate for Satoshi departure, but that happens if Saylor has a sudden accident tragedy then his ownership cannot be returned.

comments.author: crwth
comments.body: He really sees it as a long-term asset, and he even plans to leave it for future generations. It’s quite different from Satoshi, but it’s for everyone, right? Since there are fewer in circulation, the demand could be high, and because of that, the price could be higher.That would be his legacy, then, and it’s a good one, in my opinion.

comments.author: Mpamaegbu
comments.body: Quote from: Rikafip on October 22, 2024, 03:31:45 PMAnd the same thing goes for Warren Buffer who also plans to do the same thing with his billions.That's the thing with reaching for the sky. One gets there and discovers there's nothing to it. At that point, most begin to lose excitement and then do irrational stuff. That's what I see here. How on earth would anyone not have anyone they can bequeath their wealth, even if it's not a sibling or blood relation? At least, they should've someone who finds favour with them. I don't know what would influence such a mindset to embark on such thought. Just imagine having a favourite uncle who dies and leaves no family member a dime. It's going to hurt.

comments.author: OgNasty
comments.body: I think this will have to fall into the category of I will believe it when I see it. I also think he’s just talking about his personally owned Bitcoin. I don’t think he’s planning on robbing the Microstrategy holdings and burning them. So it is less of a big deal than is being made of it. We don’t even know how many BTC he has.
